definition.text: Cloud computing delivers computing services‚Äîservers, storage, databases, networking, software‚Äîover the internet ('the cloud'). It offers faster innovation, flexible resources, and economies of scale.

keyConcepts.name: Cloud Service Models
keyConcepts.concept:
IaaS (Infrastructure as a Service)
  ‚Üí Virtual machines, storage, networks
  ‚Üí AWS EC2, Azure VMs, GCP Compute

PaaS (Platform as a Service)
  ‚Üí Managed platforms for apps
  ‚Üí Heroku, AWS Elastic Beanstalk

SaaS (Software as a Service)
  ‚Üí Ready-to-use applications
  ‚Üí Gmail, Salesforce, Slack
keyConcepts.meaning: Different levels of abstraction and management

keyConcepts.name: Why Cloud?
keyConcepts.concept:
‚úì No upfront hardware costs
‚úì Pay for what you use
‚úì Scale up/down as needed
‚úì Global deployment in minutes
‚úì Focus on code, not infrastructure
‚úì Built-in redundancy and backups
keyConcepts.meaning: Cloud reduces costs and increases agility

examples.question: Which cloud service model should I use?

steps.result: Maximum control ‚Üí IaaS, Minimal ops ‚Üí PaaS
Small team without ops ‚Üí PaaS or SaaS

examples.finalAnswer: Choose based on control needs, team size, and expertise

definition.text: Amazon Web Services (AWS) is the leading cloud platform offering over 200 services. Understanding core services is essential for building modern applications.

keyConcepts.name: Compute Services
keyConcepts.concept:
EC2: Virtual servers
  ‚Üí Full control, any workload

Lambda: Serverless functions
  ‚Üí Pay per execution, auto-scales

ECS/EKS: Container orchestration
  ‚Üí Run Docker containers at scale

Elastic Beanstalk: PaaS
  ‚Üí Deploy without managing infra
keyConcepts.meaning: Different compute options for different needs

keyConcepts.name: Storage Services
keyConcepts.concept:
S3: Object storage
  ‚Üí Files, images, backups, static hosting

EBS: Block storage
  ‚Üí Attached to EC2 instances

RDS: Managed databases
  ‚Üí MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server

DynamoDB: NoSQL database
  ‚Üí Key-value, millisecond latency
keyConcepts.meaning: Choose storage based on data type and access patterns

definition.text: Serverless computing lets you run code without managing servers. The cloud provider handles all infrastructure, and you pay only for the compute time you consume.

keyConcepts.name: How Serverless Works
keyConcepts.concept:
1. Write a function (handler)
2. Deploy to cloud provider
3. Function triggered by events
   - HTTP request
   - File upload
   - Database change
   - Schedule (cron)
4. Provider runs your code
5. Scales automatically
6. Pay only for execution time

keyConcepts.name: Pros and Cons
keyConcepts.concept:
Pros:
‚úì No server management
‚úì Auto-scaling
‚úì Pay per use
‚úì Quick deployment

Cons:
‚úó Cold start latency
‚úó Execution time limits
‚úó Vendor lock-in
‚úó Debugging complexity
keyConcepts.meaning: Serverless isn't always the best choice

definition.text: Cloud security encompasses policies, controls, and technologies that protect cloud-based systems and data. Understanding the shared responsibility model is crucial.

keyConcepts.name: Shared Responsibility Model
keyConcepts.concept:
Cloud Provider Responsible For:
‚Ä¢ Physical infrastructure
‚Ä¢ Network infrastructure
‚Ä¢ Hypervisor security

Customer Responsible For:
‚Ä¢ Data encryption
‚Ä¢ Access management (IAM)
‚Ä¢ Network configuration
‚Ä¢ Application security
‚Ä¢ Operating system patches
keyConcepts.meaning: Security is a shared duty between provider and customer

keyConcepts.name: Identity & Access Management
keyConcepts.concept:
Users: Individual people/services
Groups: Collection of users
Roles: Temporary permissions
Policies: Define permissions

Principle of Least Privilege:
‚Üí Grant only necessary permissions
keyConcepts.meaning: Control who can access what in your cloud

definition.text: Kubernetes (K8s) is an open-source container orchestration platform. It automates deploying, scaling, and managing containerized applications across clusters of hosts.

keyConcepts.name: Core Concepts
keyConcepts.concept:
Pod: Smallest deployable unit
  ‚Üí One or more containers

Deployment: Manages pod replicas
  ‚Üí Rolling updates, scaling

Service: Exposes pods
  ‚Üí Load balancing, discovery

Ingress: External access
  ‚Üí HTTP routing, TLS

keyConcepts.name: Essential kubectl Commands
keyConcepts.concept:
kubectl get pods          # List pods
kubectl get deployments   # List deployments
kubectl apply -f app.yaml # Deploy config
kubectl logs <pod>        # View logs
kubectl exec -it <pod> -- bash  # Shell into pod
kubectl scale deploy/app --replicas=3
keyConcepts.meaning: kubectl is the CLI for Kubernetes

examples.question: Deploy an app to Kubernetes
examples.codeExample:
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: my-app
spec:
  replicas: 3
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: my-app
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: my-app
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: my-app
        image: my-app:1.0
        ports:
        - containerPort: 3000
